summary: I luv all your Captain Marvel posts! I know Yon-Rogg is a "villain" but I've seen the movie twice now and in my opinion he cared...
question: I luv all your Captain Marvel posts! I know Yon-Rogg is a "villain" but I've seen the movie twice now and in my opinion he cared for Carol. I mean he saved her life by taking her from earth. What do you think?
answer:
iufhueiwhf umm there are so many points I want to touch on but I also don’t feel like writing an essay lol. 

For starters I think he is a villain not a “villain.” I think he’s a good example of the proverb “the road to hell is paved with good intentions.” When he found carol I think he admired her tenacity, but when she absorbed the blast he saw taking her as an opportunity to harness her power. So he abducted her and then gave her a transfusion with his blood. This act happened to save her life, and for that reason he doesn’t see it as kidnapping. But that’s still what it was. 

We don’t see carol’s six years with the kree, but from seeing the movie three times, watching cast interviews and reading some passages from the book I agree with you that he cared for her. He was her most trusted confidant, she was his favorite student, their relationship was defined as “tender” and they had undeniable chemistry to viewers. But even though they formed a close bond, he still lied to her for 6 years. Did he do this because he is evil? No. But that doesn’t mean he was right or good. 

When carol was missing, he clearly cared about her safety and well being. His nonverbal communication demonstrated that… And then during their two phone conversations he proceeded to gaslight her. That’s emotional abuse, no question. Did he mean malice towards her? No. But he still did it. 

I’m going to stop there because once I get going analyzing it’s hard to stop lol. He is a villain, and he cares about carol. Those two things aren’t mutually exclusive.

summary: Personal Space - Carol Danvers
title: Personal Space - Carol Danvers
body:
Carol Danvers is an alien, in a sense. She’s grown and matured in a culture that holds emotions hostage….and lacks education on personal space. You don’t so much mind when she invaded your bubble, but what irks you is that she can’t see why you blush every time she does.

“So, let me get this right,” you began, pushing the button on the coffee maker as you turned to face your new guests, “she’s an alien from a far off planet, sent here to stop the infiltration of shapeshifting aliens? Don’t you see the connection, Nick?”

“Well yeah, I haven’t not thought about that but-” Before Nick could finish, Carol, alien in question, was facing you. Her nose just barely brushed against your own as her deep brown eyes stared you down. Unlike Nick’s eyes, that glimmered with humor even in such a dire situation, Carol’s were almost alarmingly cold.

“I’m not here to hurt people,” her voice mirrored her stoney expression as she spoke, “I’m here to end a war before more people are hurt.” It was hard to discern whether it was Carol’s close proximity to you or the serious glint in her eyes, but your breath caught in your throat. Warmth flooded your face to reveal a your feeling of embarrassment.

“Sorry for my assumption,” you said softly, your voice betraying you. With her so close, you could see flecks of gold in the rich brown of her irises. For an alien, she had very human, and very pretty, eyes. It was then you noticed, despite how close she was already, Carol leaned in further with furrowed brows. Her lips parted as if she were about to respond but Nick, watching the scene carry on, cleared his throat.

“Are we done, cos, we got a world to save still?” Still peering into your eyes, Carol nodded. A moment later she was standing in front of your window, gazing out across the city. You spared a glance at Nick who merely shrugged, “maybe she likes you?”

-

“When I agreed to help you, this is not what I imagined,” you said through gritted teeth. Nick let out a laugh, nearly spilling his glass of sweet iced tea as you spun Monica around.

“Working with SHIELD comes with it’s perks! You should reconsider my offer, Y/N, you’d make a fine agent.” Monica giggled as you set her feet back down on solid dirt.

“You’re not an agent?” She asked, her brown eyes widening slightly as she added, “But you’re so good at fighting! You almost beat the-”

“Monica!” Maria shouted before her daughter could finish her sentence. The little girl smiled shyly, glancing over to where her mother and Carol stood on the porch. You followed her gaze, eyes locking with Carol. She looked more in her element than she did when you first met her. No longer wearing her suit, she was clad in a loose fitting shirt and jeans that, when she had first changed, made your jaw drop. You had tried your hardest not to ogle and it seemed she didn’t notice as she continued to spout on about the Cree.

Now, however, in the light of the setting Southern sun, it was hard to ignore her beauty. Even in conservation, the way she held herself was strong. It was something to admire; something about the woman that had stuck with you. You hoped that, maybe, after everything, she would stay and you could admire her some more.

“Y/N?” Nick’s voice pulled your attention away from Carol back to the lounging form of your friend. He raised his eyebrows, gesturing towards Monica who still stood at your side.

“Oh, sorry, no. No, I’m not an agent.” The little girl frowned, as if asking why.

“Should be though,” Nick shouted, “you’re wasting your potential in that stinking office.” You were about to fire back, something mean about being able to shoot straight, but Carol beat you to the punch.

“But then she’d have to wear one of those stupid hats, Fury,” she joked. A smile spread against your lips, sending her a grateful glance to the woman from over your shoulder. Monica giggled before pulling on your hand to get your attention.

“We could make new hats for SHIELD! Maybe then you’ll be an agent?” You bit your bottom lip, finding it hard to say no to the little girl before you with her wide eyes. Sighing, you glimpsed back up at Carol who, much to your surprise, was smiling too.

“I guess it’s worth a try, yeah?” You said, bringing an impossibly large grin to Monica’s lips. The girl cheered before taking your hand to lead you back inside the house. She raced up the steps, pulling you along and through the door. If it wasn’t for Carol grabbing your arm, you would have been covered in glue and fabric pieces.

“I actually need Y/N’s help for minute, Lieutenant Trouble. That okay?” Monica’s gaze jumped from you to Carol and back again before nodding with a smile. Before you could protest, she darted into the house with Maria following after he daughter.

“What is it?” You ask, turning to face the blonde. She leaned in close, much like the first time you met her, and a blush immediately rose to your cheeks. Carol’s brows furrowed when she noticed the flush, cocking her head to the side.

“Why does your face do that?” She reached a hand up and brushed her fingers against your cheek. The touch sent a shock through you, tickling down your spine and nearly coaxed your eyes to close. Before you could, you lifted a hand to grab her wrist, pulling it away from your cheek. Somehow you managed to catch your breath enough to reply.

“You would think an advanced alien race would know what a blush is,” you drawled, “and how not to invade one’s personal space.” A smile formed on Carol’s lips as she leaned a little closer. Another thing to admire: her daring demeanor.

“I’m not an alien, not really,” she said, referencing her life altering revelation that had occurred a mere few hours ago. You nodded, licking your lips slightly in the hopes to distract yourself from how she had licked her own.

“Well, you’re still out of this world,” you said, nearly laughing at your own tilted attempt at flirting. However, the laugh that rang out from Carol’s lips gave you a spark of hope. It was such a lovely sound and part of you wondered how you had gone so long without hearing it.

“Smooth,” she teased, “I’ll have to remember that one.” You let out a nervous laugh, shifting your gaze to your hands. It was then you realized you still had your fingers around her wrist. Quickly, to negate the tension, you let her go.

“So, uh, what did you need?” You took a step back so you could more comfortably talk with her, but Carol leaned in again. That hint of joy that your joke had caused dwindled until it was replaced with a solemnity that scared you slightly.

“They’re almost done with the ship,” she said jerking her head over to where the Skrulls were working on the place she had stolen. “When we go up there, I want you to stay behind.”

“Um, what? Excuse me?” Your light hearted banter and hope died when the words sunk in. “If Nick is going, if you’re going, then I am too. We’ve done too much to-”

“Y/N” she interrupted, her expression morphing from one of gravity to one of desperate earnestness. “Please, I need to know that you’re…that Monica is with someone capable. Maria’s parents wouldn’t be able to fight if something goes wrong.” You bit the inside of your cheek, nodding until your gaze hit the floor. It made sense, but it didn’t numb the sting.

“Someone capable,” you repeated, lifting your gaze to Carol’s, “that’s all I am, yeah?” Before she could reply or dare to close the gap between you, you stormed into the house. “You got it, Captain,” you shouted, “I’ll stay put.”

-

“So this is it,” you said, walking up to Carol. She was glowing under the kitchen lights of the Rambeau home. Despite saving countless lives, there she was before you, doing the dishes. “You saved, not only Earth but a few dozen, million people. Congratulations.”

“Yeah,” she said, trying to find a way to be humble, “I guess I did.” You smiled as you settled to stand beside her. Grabbing a rag, you helped speed the cleaning process along. Every now and then, you hand would brush against hers, sending little bolts up your arms.

“So what now?” You stopped cleaning and turned your head to look into her eyes. Carol was finishing up drying the plate you had given her, avoiding your eyes. When she was done, she sighed and turned to face you. Her eyes were bright, light with the weight of the world(s) off her shoulders for a moment of respite.

“I’m going to help the Skrull, they deserve, they need, a home after all the Cree have stolen from them. I have to make it up to them, it’s what’s right.” You nodded, swallowing the words that threatened to pour out of your mouth. Despite your best efforts, they did anyway.

“It’ not your debt to pay, you know. You could stay here.” You lifted your eyes to hold her gaze, expecting to she a very offended and pissed off woman before you. However, Carol took you in with a softness you had hardly ever seen from her. She stepped towards you until your noses were nearly touching.

“Would you want that?” Her tone is ribbing, bordering on taunting if it weren’t for the note of genuine interest. Your eyes flickered from hers to her lips, trying hard to remain focused despite her closeness.

“I would,” you admit, taking notice of the smile that bloomed on her lips when you did. Suddenly feeling like you overstepped, took something, namely your feelings, too far, you added, “I would definitely feel safer, that’s for sure.”

“Ha, yeah, you and everyone else,” she teased, leaning closer, “but you, is there any reason why you-”

“Ladies! Maria has sent me to get desert,” Nick announced as he paraded into the kitchen. Monica and Talo’s daughter were hot on his heels, eager for the secret sweets. You immediately pulled away from Carol and offered them all a smile.

“Let’s get it then, shall we?” The girls giggled and Carol watched on as you helped them. Her eyes never once left you, not even when you said your final goodbyes. An all too quick hug, her hand on your head to hold you close. You could remember the look in her eyes as she took off with the Skrulls. She wasn’t sad, presay, but there was a glimmer of something lost as she took to the skies.

-

“So what does it do exactly?” Bruce asked for the hundredth time that evening. You rolled your eyes, pushing away from the desk full of files labelled in red. Missing Persons.

“Nick never told me exactly,” you explained, “not even when I officially joined SHIELD. He just told me that I would know when it happens.” Bruce let out a dissatisfied huff and continued to watching the blinking light on the pager. You did too, reflecting on the time when you last remembered using one. It was vivid in your mind, handing the device to Carol after Nick had alerted the entirety of Skrull invaders to his presence. It was fond looking back, especially now that there was only a few left to muse on memories.

You were turning back to your desk with the thought of Thanos and the hunger of vengeance churning in your mind when Bruce gasped. Looking over your shoulder, you gasped too. The blinking had stopped. You rushed from your seat and pressed your face to the glass. The life of the device flickered once before it went black.

“Get the team,” you said and Bruce darted off. Sadly, they didn’t have much to offer in the form of suggestions. Steve was still skeptical about the device and its significance, while Natasha was adamant about its purpose.

“It was important to Fury,” you agreed, “we should keep an eye on it.” You turned on your heels to get back to work but nearly ran face first into someone. If it hadn’t been for the hand that grabbed your arm, you would have landed hard against the floor. Your eyes adjusted, taking in the sight of your savor.

“Who are you?”

“Carol?” Those same eyes, still bright, smiled down at you. She pulled you back to your feet, close to her own body. “You haven’t changed,” you teased, noting the lack of room between you. She grinned softly, but there was a darkness in her expression that, you feared, mirrored your own.

“You haven’t either, or your want of personal space.” You were half tempted to laugh at her jab, but instead you wrapped your arms around her in a snug embrace. Her strong arms joined around your shoulders, holding your body flush to her own.

“You know her, Y/N?” Steve asked, blue eyes wide. You nodded and bit your bottom lip as you still trained your gaze on Carol. Still as awe-inspiring as ever.

“I do,” you said, turning in Carol’s arms. “Avengers, this is Carol Danvers.”

-

“Stubborn fool,” Carol grumbled, shaking her head as you told her what had happened to Nick. “He should have paged me earlier.”

“There wasn’t anytime,” you explained, “plus he learned that from you, you know.” Carol chuckled from her chair seated across from you. You leaned over, extending your hand across the coffee table. She mirrored your actions, entangling your fingers together when your hands met in the middle. “I’m happy you’re here now, though.”

“Me too,” she hummed, “I was going to come back.”

“You were?” You asked, brows knitted together in confusion. “Why?” Carol pulled our hand up, drawing you to your feet. Soon, she was standing before you, her face a mere inches away from your own. Just like old times.
“I missed you,” she whispered, before pressing her lips to yours. You melted into the touch, your hand trailing up to her blonde hair. Your fingers grew tangled in the locks as you drew her face closer. Her lips were smooth against your own, the kiss full of the tension that had gathered between the two of you from all those years apart.

“I missed you too,” you replied when she pulled away. “I missed having you in my bubble.” A laugh passed over her lips, the same one that echoed in your memories. Even in the darkness surrounding you know, the darkness shrouding the entire universe, you were more than overjoyed to hear that laugh again.

“You’re not an agent?” She asked, her brown eyes widening slightly as she added, “But you’re so good at fighting! You almost beat the-”

“Monica!” Maria shouted before her daughter could finish her sentence. The little girl smiled shyly, glancing over to where her mother and Carol stood on the porch. You followed her gaze, eyes locking with Carol. She looked more in her element than she did when you first met her. No longer wearing her suit, she was clad in a loose fitting shirt and jeans that, when she had first changed, made your jaw drop. You had tried your hardest not to ogle and it seemed she didn’t notice as she continued to spout on about the Cree.

Now, however, in the light of the setting Southern sun, it was hard to ignore her beauty. Even in conservation, the way she held herself was strong. It was something to admire; something about the woman that had stuck with you. You hoped that, maybe, after everything, she would stay and you could admire her some more.

“Y/N?” Nick’s voice pulled your attention away from Carol back to the lounging form of your friend. He raised his eyebrows, gesturing towards Monica who still stood at your side.

“Oh, sorry, no. No, I’m not an agent.” The little girl frowned, as if asking why.

“Should be though,” Nick shouted, “you’re wasting your potential in that stinking office.” You were about to fire back, something mean about being able to shoot straight, but Carol beat you to the punch.

“But then she’d have to wear one of those stupid hats, Fury,” she joked. A smile spread against your lips, sending her a grateful glance to the woman from over your shoulder. Monica giggled before pulling on your hand to get your attention.

“We could make new hats for SHIELD! Maybe then you’ll be an agent?” You bit your bottom lip, finding it hard to say no to the little girl before you with her wide eyes. Sighing, you glimpsed back up at Carol who, much to your surprise, was smiling too.

“I guess it’s worth a try, yeah?” You said, bringing an impossibly large grin to Monica’s lips. The girl cheered before taking your hand to lead you back inside the house. She raced up the steps, pulling you along and through the door. If it wasn’t for Carol grabbing your arm, you would have been covered in glue and fabric pieces.

“I actually need Y/N’s help for minute, Lieutenant Trouble. That okay?” Monica’s gaze jumped from you to Carol and back again before nodding with a smile. Before you could protest, she darted into the house with Maria following after he daughter.

“What is it?” You ask, turning to face the blonde. She leaned in close, much like the first time you met her, and a blush immediately rose to your cheeks. Carol’s brows furrowed when she noticed the flush, cocking her head to the side.

“Why does your face do that?” She reached a hand up and brushed her fingers against your cheek. The touch sent a shock through you, tickling down your spine and nearly coaxed your eyes to close. Before you could, you lifted a hand to grab her wrist, pulling it away from your cheek. Somehow you managed to catch your breath enough to reply.

“You would think an advanced alien race would know what a blush is,” you drawled, “and how not to invade one’s personal space.” A smile formed on Carol’s lips as she leaned a little closer. Another thing to admire: her daring demeanor.

“I’m not an alien, not really,” she said, referencing her life altering revelation that had occurred a mere few hours ago. You nodded, licking your lips slightly in the hopes to distract yourself from how she had licked her own.

“Well, you’re still out of this world,” you said, nearly laughing at your own tilted attempt at flirting. However, the laugh that rang out from Carol’s lips gave you a spark of hope. It was such a lovely sound and part of you wondered how you had gone so long without hearing it.

“Smooth,” she teased, “I’ll have to remember that one.” You let out a nervous laugh, shifting your gaze to your hands. It was then you realized you still had your fingers around her wrist. Quickly, to negate the tension, you let her go.

“So, uh, what did you need?” You took a step back so you could more comfortably talk with her, but Carol leaned in again. That hint of joy that your joke had caused dwindled until it was replaced with a solemnity that scared you slightly.

“They’re almost done with the ship,” she said jerking her head over to where the Skrulls were working on the place she had stolen. “When we go up there, I want you to stay behind.”

“Um, what? Excuse me?” Your light hearted banter and hope died when the words sunk in. “If Nick is going, if you’re going, then I am too. We’ve done too much to-”

“Y/N” she interrupted, her expression morphing from one of gravity to one of desperate earnestness. “Please, I need to know that you’re…that Monica is with someone capable. Maria’s parents wouldn’t be able to fight if something goes wrong.” You bit the inside of your cheek, nodding until your gaze hit the floor. It made sense, but it didn’t numb the sting.

“Someone capable,” you repeated, lifting your gaze to Carol’s, “that’s all I am, yeah?” Before she could reply or dare to close the gap between you, you stormed into the house. “You got it, Captain,” you shouted, “I’ll stay put.”

-

reblog.comment:
Carol Danvers is an alien, in a sense. She’s grown and matured in a culture that holds emotions hostage….and lacks education on personal space. You don’t so much mind when she invaded your bubble, but what irks you is that she can’t see why you blush every time she does.

“So, let me get this right,” you began, pushing the button on the coffee maker as you turned to face your new guests, “she’s an alien from a far off planet, sent here to stop the infiltration of shapeshifting aliens? Don’t you see the connection, Nick?”

“Well yeah, I haven’t not thought about that but-” Before Nick could finish, Carol, alien in question, was facing you. Her nose just barely brushed against your own as her deep brown eyes stared you down. Unlike Nick’s eyes, that glimmered with humor even in such a dire situation, Carol’s were almost alarmingly cold.

“I’m not here to hurt people,” her voice mirrored her stoney expression as she spoke, “I’m here to end a war before more people are hurt.” It was hard to discern whether it was Carol’s close proximity to you or the serious glint in her eyes, but your breath caught in your throat. Warmth flooded your face to reveal a your feeling of embarrassment.

“Sorry for my assumption,” you said softly, your voice betraying you. With her so close, you could see flecks of gold in the rich brown of her irises. For an alien, she had very human, and very pretty, eyes. It was then you noticed, despite how close she was already, Carol leaned in further with furrowed brows. Her lips parted as if she were about to respond but Nick, watching the scene carry on, cleared his throat.

“Are we done, cos, we got a world to save still?” Still peering into your eyes, Carol nodded. A moment later she was standing in front of your window, gazing out across the city. You spared a glance at Nick who merely shrugged, “maybe she likes you?”

[[MORE]]

“So this is it,” you said, walking up to Carol. She was glowing under the kitchen lights of the Rambeau home. Despite saving countless lives, there she was before you, doing the dishes. “You saved, not only Earth but a few dozen, million people. Congratulations.”

“Yeah,” she said, trying to find a way to be humble, “I guess I did.” You smiled as you settled to stand beside her. Grabbing a rag, you helped speed the cleaning process along. Every now and then, you hand would brush against hers, sending little bolts up your arms.

“So what now?” You stopped cleaning and turned your head to look into her eyes. Carol was finishing up drying the plate you had given her, avoiding your eyes. When she was done, she sighed and turned to face you. Her eyes were bright, light with the weight of the world(s) off her shoulders for a moment of respite.

“I’m going to help the Skrull, they deserve, they need, a home after all the Cree have stolen from them. I have to make it up to them, it’s what’s right.” You nodded, swallowing the words that threatened to pour out of your mouth. Despite your best efforts, they did anyway.

“It’ not your debt to pay, you know. You could stay here.” You lifted your eyes to hold her gaze, expecting to she a very offended and pissed off woman before you. However, Carol took you in with a softness you had hardly ever seen from her. She stepped towards you until your noses were nearly touching.

“Would you want that?” Her tone is ribbing, bordering on taunting if it weren’t for the note of genuine interest. Your eyes flickered from hers to her lips, trying hard to remain focused despite her closeness.

“I would,” you admit, taking notice of the smile that bloomed on her lips when you did. Suddenly feeling like you overstepped, took something, namely your feelings, too far, you added, “I would definitely feel safer, that’s for sure.”

“Ha, yeah, you and everyone else,” she teased, leaning closer, “but you, is there any reason why you-”

“Ladies! Maria has sent me to get desert,” Nick announced as he paraded into the kitchen. Monica and Talo’s daughter were hot on his heels, eager for the secret sweets. You immediately pulled away from Carol and offered them all a smile.

“Let’s get it then, shall we?” The girls giggled and Carol watched on as you helped them. Her eyes never once left you, not even when you said your final goodbyes. An all too quick hug, her hand on your head to hold you close. You could remember the look in her eyes as she took off with the Skrulls. She wasn’t sad, presay, but there was a glimmer of something lost as she took to the skies.

-

“So what does it do exactly?” Bruce asked for the hundredth time that evening. You rolled your eyes, pushing away from the desk full of files labelled in red. Missing Persons.

“Nick never told me exactly,” you explained, “not even when I officially joined SHIELD. He just told me that I would know when it happens.” Bruce let out a dissatisfied huff and continued to watching the blinking light on the pager. You did too, reflecting on the time when you last remembered using one. It was vivid in your mind, handing the device to Carol after Nick had alerted the entirety of Skrull invaders to his presence. It was fond looking back, especially now that there was only a few left to muse on memories.

You were turning back to your desk with the thought of Thanos and the hunger of vengeance churning in your mind when Bruce gasped. Looking over your shoulder, you gasped too. The blinking had stopped. You rushed from your seat and pressed your face to the glass. The life of the device flickered once before it went black.

“Get the team,” you said and Bruce darted off. Sadly, they didn’t have much to offer in the form of suggestions. Steve was still skeptical about the device and its significance, while Natasha was adamant about its purpose.

“It was important to Fury,” you agreed, “we should keep an eye on it.” You turned on your heels to get back to work but nearly ran face first into someone. If it hadn’t been for the hand that grabbed your arm, you would have landed hard against the floor. Your eyes adjusted, taking in the sight of your savor.

“Who are you?”

“Carol?” Those same eyes, still bright, smiled down at you. She pulled you back to your feet, close to her own body. “You haven’t changed,” you teased, noting the lack of room between you. She grinned softly, but there was a darkness in her expression that, you feared, mirrored your own.

“You haven’t either, or your want of personal space.” You were half tempted to laugh at her jab, but instead you wrapped your arms around her in a snug embrace. Her strong arms joined around your shoulders, holding your body flush to her own.

“You know her, Y/N?” Steve asked, blue eyes wide. You nodded and bit your bottom lip as you still trained your gaze on Carol. Still as awe-inspiring as ever.

“I do,” you said, turning in Carol’s arms. “Avengers, this is Carol Danvers.”

-

“Stubborn fool,” Carol grumbled, shaking her head as you told her what had happened to Nick. “He should have paged me earlier.”

“There wasn’t anytime,” you explained, “plus he learned that from you, you know.” Carol chuckled from her chair seated across from you. You leaned over, extending your hand across the coffee table. She mirrored your actions, entangling your fingers together when your hands met in the middle. “I’m happy you’re here now, though.”

“Me too,” she hummed, “I was going to come back.”

“You were?” You asked, brows knitted together in confusion. “Why?” Carol pulled our hand up, drawing you to your feet. Soon, she was standing before you, her face a mere inches away from your own. Just like old times.
“I missed you,” she whispered, before pressing her lips to yours. You melted into the touch, your hand trailing up to her blonde hair. Your fingers grew tangled in the locks as you drew her face closer. Her lips were smooth against your own, the kiss full of the tension that had gathered between the two of you from all those years apart.

“I missed you too,” you replied when she pulled away. “I missed having you in my bubble.” A laugh passed over her lips, the same one that echoed in your memories. Even in the darkness surrounding you know, the darkness shrouding the entire universe, you were more than overjoyed to hear that laugh again.

“I missed you,” she whispered, before pressing her lips to yours. You melted into the touch, your hand trailing up to her blonde hair. Your fingers grew tangled in the locks as you drew her face closer. Her lips were smooth against your own, the kiss full of the tension that had gathered between the two of you from all those years apart.

“I missed you too,” you replied when she pulled away. “I missed having you in my bubble.” A laugh passed over her lips, the same one that echoed in your memories. Even in the darkness surrounding you know, the darkness shrouding the entire universe, you were more than overjoyed to hear that laugh again.
trail.content:
Carol Danvers is an alien, in a sense. She’s grown and matured in a culture that holds emotions hostage….and lacks education on personal space. You don’t so much mind when she invaded your bubble, but what irks you is that she can’t see why you blush every time she does.

“So, let me get this right,” you began, pushing the button on the coffee maker as you turned to face your new guests, “she’s an alien from a far off planet, sent here to stop the infiltration of shapeshifting aliens? Don’t you see the connection, Nick?”

“Well yeah, I haven’t not thought about that but-” Before Nick could finish, Carol, alien in question, was facing you. Her nose just barely brushed against your own as her deep brown eyes stared you down. Unlike Nick’s eyes, that glimmered with humor even in such a dire situation, Carol’s were almost alarmingly cold.

“I’m not here to hurt people,” her voice mirrored her stoney expression as she spoke, “I’m here to end a war before more people are hurt.” It was hard to discern whether it was Carol’s close proximity to you or the serious glint in her eyes, but your breath caught in your throat. Warmth flooded your face to reveal a your feeling of embarrassment.

“Sorry for my assumption,” you said softly, your voice betraying you. With her so close, you could see flecks of gold in the rich brown of her irises. For an alien, she had very human, and very pretty, eyes. It was then you noticed, despite how close she was already, Carol leaned in further with furrowed brows. Her lips parted as if she were about to respond but Nick, watching the scene carry on, cleared his throat.

“Are we done, cos, we got a world to save still?” Still peering into your eyes, Carol nodded. A moment later she was standing in front of your window, gazing out across the city. You spared a glance at Nick who merely shrugged, “maybe she likes you?”

-

“When I agreed to help you, this is not what I imagined,” you said through gritted teeth. Nick let out a laugh, nearly spilling his glass of sweet iced tea as you spun Monica around.

“Working with SHIELD comes with it’s perks! You should reconsider my offer, Y/N, you’d make a fine agent.” Monica giggled as you set her feet back down on solid dirt.

“You’re not an agent?” She asked, her brown eyes widening slightly as she added, “But you’re so good at fighting! You almost beat the-”

“Monica!” Maria shouted before her daughter could finish her sentence. The little girl smiled shyly, glancing over to where her mother and Carol stood on the porch. You followed her gaze, eyes locking with Carol. She looked more in her element than she did when you first met her. No longer wearing her suit, she was clad in a loose fitting shirt and jeans that, when she had first changed, made your jaw drop. You had tried your hardest not to ogle and it seemed she didn’t notice as she continued to spout on about the Cree.

Now, however, in the light of the setting Southern sun, it was hard to ignore her beauty. Even in conservation, the way she held herself was strong. It was something to admire; something about the woman that had stuck with you. You hoped that, maybe, after everything, she would stay and you could admire her some more.

“Y/N?” Nick’s voice pulled your attention away from Carol back to the lounging form of your friend. He raised his eyebrows, gesturing towards Monica who still stood at your side.

“Oh, sorry, no. No, I’m not an agent.” The little girl frowned, as if asking why.

“Should be though,” Nick shouted, “you’re wasting your potential in that stinking office.” You were about to fire back, something mean about being able to shoot straight, but Carol beat you to the punch.

“But then she’d have to wear one of those stupid hats, Fury,” she joked. A smile spread against your lips, sending her a grateful glance to the woman from over your shoulder. Monica giggled before pulling on your hand to get your attention.

“We could make new hats for SHIELD! Maybe then you’ll be an agent?” You bit your bottom lip, finding it hard to say no to the little girl before you with her wide eyes. Sighing, you glimpsed back up at Carol who, much to your surprise, was smiling too.

“I guess it’s worth a try, yeah?” You said, bringing an impossibly large grin to Monica’s lips. The girl cheered before taking your hand to lead you back inside the house. She raced up the steps, pulling you along and through the door. If it wasn’t for Carol grabbing your arm, you would have been covered in glue and fabric pieces.

“I actually need Y/N’s help for minute, Lieutenant Trouble. That okay?” Monica’s gaze jumped from you to Carol and back again before nodding with a smile. Before you could protest, she darted into the house with Maria following after he daughter.

“What is it?” You ask, turning to face the blonde. She leaned in close, much like the first time you met her, and a blush immediately rose to your cheeks. Carol’s brows furrowed when she noticed the flush, cocking her head to the side.

“Why does your face do that?” She reached a hand up and brushed her fingers against your cheek. The touch sent a shock through you, tickling down your spine and nearly coaxed your eyes to close. Before you could, you lifted a hand to grab her wrist, pulling it away from your cheek. Somehow you managed to catch your breath enough to reply.

“You would think an advanced alien race would know what a blush is,” you drawled, “and how not to invade one’s personal space.” A smile formed on Carol’s lips as she leaned a little closer. Another thing to admire: her daring demeanor.

“I’m not an alien, not really,” she said, referencing her life altering revelation that had occurred a mere few hours ago. You nodded, licking your lips slightly in the hopes to distract yourself from how she had licked her own.

“Well, you’re still out of this world,” you said, nearly laughing at your own tilted attempt at flirting. However, the laugh that rang out from Carol’s lips gave you a spark of hope. It was such a lovely sound and part of you wondered how you had gone so long without hearing it.

“Smooth,” she teased, “I’ll have to remember that one.” You let out a nervous laugh, shifting your gaze to your hands. It was then you realized you still had your fingers around her wrist. Quickly, to negate the tension, you let her go.

“So, uh, what did you need?” You took a step back so you could more comfortably talk with her, but Carol leaned in again. That hint of joy that your joke had caused dwindled until it was replaced with a solemnity that scared you slightly.

“They’re almost done with the ship,” she said jerking her head over to where the Skrulls were working on the place she had stolen. “When we go up there, I want you to stay behind.”

“Um, what? Excuse me?” Your light hearted banter and hope died when the words sunk in. “If Nick is going, if you’re going, then I am too. We’ve done too much to-”

“Y/N” she interrupted, her expression morphing from one of gravity to one of desperate earnestness. “Please, I need to know that you’re…that Monica is with someone capable. Maria’s parents wouldn’t be able to fight if something goes wrong.” You bit the inside of your cheek, nodding until your gaze hit the floor. It made sense, but it didn’t numb the sting.

“Someone capable,” you repeated, lifting your gaze to Carol’s, “that’s all I am, yeah?” Before she could reply or dare to close the gap between you, you stormed into the house. “You got it, Captain,” you shouted, “I’ll stay put.”

-

“So this is it,” you said, walking up to Carol. She was glowing under the kitchen lights of the Rambeau home. Despite saving countless lives, there she was before you, doing the dishes. “You saved, not only Earth but a few dozen, million people. Congratulations.”

“Yeah,” she said, trying to find a way to be humble, “I guess I did.” You smiled as you settled to stand beside her. Grabbing a rag, you helped speed the cleaning process along. Every now and then, you hand would brush against hers, sending little bolts up your arms.

“So what now?” You stopped cleaning and turned your head to look into her eyes. Carol was finishing up drying the plate you had given her, avoiding your eyes. When she was done, she sighed and turned to face you. Her eyes were bright, light with the weight of the world(s) off her shoulders for a moment of respite.

“I’m going to help the Skrull, they deserve, they need, a home after all the Cree have stolen from them. I have to make it up to them, it’s what’s right.” You nodded, swallowing the words that threatened to pour out of your mouth. Despite your best efforts, they did anyway.

“It’ not your debt to pay, you know. You could stay here.” You lifted your eyes to hold her gaze, expecting to she a very offended and pissed off woman before you. However, Carol took you in with a softness you had hardly ever seen from her. She stepped towards you until your noses were nearly touching.

“Would you want that?” Her tone is ribbing, bordering on taunting if it weren’t for the note of genuine interest. Your eyes flickered from hers to her lips, trying hard to remain focused despite her closeness.

“I would,” you admit, taking notice of the smile that bloomed on her lips when you did. Suddenly feeling like you overstepped, took something, namely your feelings, too far, you added, “I would definitely feel safer, that’s for sure.”

“Ha, yeah, you and everyone else,” she teased, leaning closer, “but you, is there any reason why you-”

“Ladies! Maria has sent me to get desert,” Nick announced as he paraded into the kitchen. Monica and Talo’s daughter were hot on his heels, eager for the secret sweets. You immediately pulled away from Carol and offered them all a smile.

“Let’s get it then, shall we?” The girls giggled and Carol watched on as you helped them. Her eyes never once left you, not even when you said your final goodbyes. An all too quick hug, her hand on your head to hold you close. You could remember the look in her eyes as she took off with the Skrulls. She wasn’t sad, presay, but there was a glimmer of something lost as she took to the skies.

-

“So what does it do exactly?” Bruce asked for the hundredth time that evening. You rolled your eyes, pushing away from the desk full of files labelled in red. Missing Persons.

“Nick never told me exactly,” you explained, “not even when I officially joined SHIELD. He just told me that I would know when it happens.” Bruce let out a dissatisfied huff and continued to watching the blinking light on the pager. You did too, reflecting on the time when you last remembered using one. It was vivid in your mind, handing the device to Carol after Nick had alerted the entirety of Skrull invaders to his presence. It was fond looking back, especially now that there was only a few left to muse on memories.

You were turning back to your desk with the thought of Thanos and the hunger of vengeance churning in your mind when Bruce gasped. Looking over your shoulder, you gasped too. The blinking had stopped. You rushed from your seat and pressed your face to the glass. The life of the device flickered once before it went black.

“Get the team,” you said and Bruce darted off. Sadly, they didn’t have much to offer in the form of suggestions. Steve was still skeptical about the device and its significance, while Natasha was adamant about its purpose.

“It was important to Fury,” you agreed, “we should keep an eye on it.” You turned on your heels to get back to work but nearly ran face first into someone. If it hadn’t been for the hand that grabbed your arm, you would have landed hard against the floor. Your eyes adjusted, taking in the sight of your savor.

“Who are you?”

“Carol?” Those same eyes, still bright, smiled down at you. She pulled you back to your feet, close to her own body. “You haven’t changed,” you teased, noting the lack of room between you. She grinned softly, but there was a darkness in her expression that, you feared, mirrored your own.

“You haven’t either, or your want of personal space.” You were half tempted to laugh at her jab, but instead you wrapped your arms around her in a snug embrace. Her strong arms joined around your shoulders, holding your body flush to her own.

“You know her, Y/N?” Steve asked, blue eyes wide. You nodded and bit your bottom lip as you still trained your gaze on Carol. Still as awe-inspiring as ever.

“I do,” you said, turning in Carol’s arms. “Avengers, this is Carol Danvers.”

-

“Stubborn fool,” Carol grumbled, shaking her head as you told her what had happened to Nick. “He should have paged me earlier.”

“There wasn’t anytime,” you explained, “plus he learned that from you, you know.” Carol chuckled from her chair seated across from you. You leaned over, extending your hand across the coffee table. She mirrored your actions, entangling your fingers together when your hands met in the middle. “I’m happy you’re here now, though.”

“Me too,” she hummed, “I was going to come back.”

“You were?” You asked, brows knitted together in confusion. “Why?” Carol pulled our hand up, drawing you to your feet. Soon, she was standing before you, her face a mere inches away from your own. Just like old times.
“I missed you,” she whispered, before pressing her lips to yours. You melted into the touch, your hand trailing up to her blonde hair. Your fingers grew tangled in the locks as you drew her face closer. Her lips were smooth against your own, the kiss full of the tension that had gathered between the two of you from all those years apart.

“I missed you too,” you replied when she pulled away. “I missed having you in my bubble.” A laugh passed over her lips, the same one that echoed in your memories. Even in the darkness surrounding you know, the darkness shrouding the entire universe, you were more than overjoyed to hear that laugh again.

summary: Us, Captain Marvel, Modern Warfare Remastered & Apex: Legends First Impressions!
title: Us, Captain Marvel, Modern Warfare Remastered & Apex: Legends First Impressions!
body:
Over the past two months, I’ve been making an effort to clear out some of my backlogs: Netflix, Switch games, PS4 games, and new movies I missed out on. But a lot of the content I’ve consumed hasn’t really been something I wanted to write about. Although I am watching the Mission: Impossible series for the first time right now, more on that later!

However, March had some pretty big movies released in theatres including Jordan Peele’s latest horror effort Us and the origin story of Marvel’s Captain Marvel; and I finally picked up a PlayStation 4 again meaning I got to finish Modern Warfare Remastered after picking it up on PS Plus in March and play a couple of games of Apex: Legends for the first time. Let’s talk!

Us

Best known for his roles in comedy, Jordan Peele made a name for himself as a writer and director with Get Out which released to critical acclaim back in 2017. Since then, Peele served as a producer on BlacKkKlansman, is the host and producer for The Twilight Zone reboot, and released his second film, Us.

Without going into any spoilers, the general premise follows a family of four on a beach Vacation who are confronted by their own doppelgangers. Us is a very well made film that uses atmosphere and tension to invoke horror rather than rely on cheap tropes like jump scares. However, it’s far from a perfect film and its plot falls apart easily when under the microscope. There’s a drastic tonal shift roughly 2/3 into the movie and narrative choices that defy the rules of the world entirely, most notably the ending which left me more frustrated than excited.

The film stars Lupita Nyong'o (The Jungle Book, Black Panther) and Winston Duke (Black Panther) in leading roles as the parents, alongside Shahadi Wright Joseph (The Lion King 2019), and Evan Alex, all of which are fantastic, particularly Nyong’o and Duke. Watching the pair play two drastically different roles was fascinating, particularly Nyong’os doppelganger Red, who acts as the leader of the group. Overall, I still found the movie to be entertaining and would recommend watching it. I like Peele’s style of film making and anticipate a bright future for the writer/director.

Marvel Studio’s Captain Marvel

Originally I planned to review Captain Marvel as I do with all Marvel films, but I’ve been struggling to compile my thoughts without a second viewing and there are too many films out this month for me to see this again so soon. First and foremost, I liked Captain Marvel a lot. It’s an MCU film and that guarantees a certain level of quality; it’s fun, action-packed, great characters, and helps build the larger universe, where we’ll see a payoff in Avengers: Endgame releasing later this month.

Captain Marvel is a prequel film that tells the origin story of the titular character Carol Danvers played by Brie Larson (Room, Kong: Skull Island). The story follows a war between two alien races known as the Kree (previously seen in Guardians of the Galaxy) and the villainous shape-shifting Skrulls, which makes its way to Earth where Carol meets a much younger Nick Fury (Samual L. Jackson), Agent Coulson (Clark Gregg), and her old friend Maria from the Air Force. The film also stars Jude Law as Carol’s Kree mentor Yon-Rogg, Ben Mendelsohn as Talos the leader of the Skrull army, and Lee Pace and Djimon Hounson reprising their Guardian’s roles as Ronan the Accuser and Korath respectively.

I’ve always been excited about Brie Larson playing Captain Marvel, but the initial trailers made her come off as a little bland and out of place. That is certainly not the case in the film. Brie Larson is fantastic as Captain Marvel and her chemistry with Samuel L. Jackson is a lot of fun to watch. It’s refreshing to see this badass female heroine and not have the focus of her story be nothing more than a love story. She’s doesn’t have a love interest at all and her relationships with the rest of the cast range from mentorship, to friend, partners, and family. Carol Danvers is trying to figure out who she is and what her purpose in the world is, nothing more. As far as origin stories go, there’s nothing done here that’s overtly original, and it feels very much like a mixture between Phase One and Phase Three MCU.

Overall, Captain Marvel is a great watch that sits somewhere in the middle of the MCU for me. It’s not one of the best, but it’s also not one of the worst. I think the cast is fantastic, she’s a great role model for young girls to look up to, especially those that like comics and superheroes, and I’m really excited to see the future of Carol Danvers now that the origin story is out of the way.

Modern Warfare Remastered

I stopped playing Call of Duty years ago at this point; I’m just not interested in playing same games year on year, especially a series that becomes increasingly more anti-consumer. But I have a strong fondness and nostalgia for the older games including the Modern Warfare trilogy and my all-time favourite, Black Ops (a game I desperately want to see given the Remastered treatment). I was really excited when MWR was first announced but I never picked it up due to a large backlog, and Activision’s steep prices like reselling the DLC on a Remastered product at a higher cost than the original…

In March, MWR was released for free on PlayStation Plus and was the first game I downloaded when I picked up a PS4 again after a couple of months without one. And after two weeks I’ve already gotten the Platinum trophy! I had a blast going back to Modern Warfare for the first time in years. I don’t think the campaign is as incredible as our memories make it out to be, but it has some fantastic moments like the mission All Ghillied Up, and characters such as Price that are later fleshed out. You can see how Modern Warfare laid the groundwork for everything we know now, and the Remastered version makes the game look and sounds fantastic. Gameplay feels a little dated, particularly the geometry as you’ll find yourself getting literally caught on door frames, but it never ruined my experience.

Modern Warfare was always known for its Multiplayer and that’s something I plan to keep coming back to for the foreseeable future. Multiplayer is a mixture between new school and old school gameplay; it’s still very chaotic, but far simpler than more recent titles. Something as simple as having set kill streaks makes me more focussed on the objective than my streak which is refreshing. Personally, I really like the addition of new weapons and maps as well. And while the loot box system is a lot friendlier than Black Ops 4, loot is my only real problem with MWR. There are too many items for too many weapons and it takes too long to earn anything meaningful without spending money. As a new player, it’s overwhelming and distracting. Whatever happened to trying to get headshots to unlock the Fall camo in MW2?

Apex: Legends Impressions

Titanfall 2 was one of my favourite games of 2016 and easily one of the most underrated games to release that year. So when I heard Respawn Entertainment was releasing a free Battle Royale set in the Titanfall universe, I knew I had to try it out. After playing for a few hours the other night and securing my first win after three games, I’ve already bought the Battle Pass.

Apex: Legends is a squad-based Battle Royale with each game featuring 20 squads of 3 fighting it out for victory. Players can choose from 9 Legend characters to play as (with more coming each season) each with their own unique play styles and abilities, think Fortnite meets Overwatch, which helps distinguish Apex from the other BR games out there. Apex looks, sounds, and plays like a Titanfall game only there’s no Titans or wall running so the overall pace is slower. And the arsenal is taken directly from Titanfall 2 so anyone familiar with those games will feel at home pretty quickly. 

Respawn Entertainment is a developer I like and want to see succeed because they make high-quality games that are fun to play. I also really like the Battle Pass system in Apex because it rewards hardcore players. If you reach Tier 100 and unlock all the rewards, you’ve also unlocked enough Apex coins to buy next Battle Pass without paying anything extra. I’m more than happy to buy the Battle Pass to support a great game that was free, and if that gets me all of the future content because I love the game and play it a lot, fantastic.

Looking for more from me? Follow me on Twitter to keep up to date with my latest posts, video game related nonsense, or if you just want to say hey!
body_abstract:
Over the past two months, I’ve been making an effort to clear out some of my backlogs: Netflix, Switch games, PS4 games, and new movies I missed out on. But a lot of the content I’ve consumed hasn’t really been something I wanted to write about. Although I am watching the Mission: Impossible series for the first time right now, more on that later!

However, March had some pretty big movies released in theatres including Jordan Peele’s latest horror effort Us and the origin story of Marvel’s Captain Marvel; and I finally picked up a PlayStation 4 again meaning I got to finish Modern Warfare Remastered after picking it up on PS Plus in March and play a couple of games of Apex: Legends for the first time. Let’s talk!

But a lot of the content I’ve consumed hasn’t really been something I wanted to write about. Although I am watching the Mission: Impossible series for the first time right now, more on that later!

However, March had some pretty big movies released in theatres including Jordan Peele’s latest horror effort Us and the origin story of Marvel’s Captain Marvel; and I finally picked up a PlayStation 4 again meaning I got to finish Modern Warfare Remastered after picking it up on PS Plus in March and play a couple of games of Apex: Legends for the first time. Let’s talk!

[[MORE]]

Us

Best known for his roles in comedy, Jordan Peele made a name for himself as a writer and director with Get Out which released to critical acclaim back in 2017. Since then, Peele served as a producer on BlacKkKlansman, is the host and producer for The Twilight Zone reboot, and released his second film, Us.

Without going into any spoilers, the general premise follows a family of four on a beach Vacation who are confronted by their own doppelgangers. Us is a very well made film that uses atmosphere and tension to invoke horror rather than rely on cheap tropes like jump scares. However, it’s far from a perfect film and its plot falls apart easily when under the microscope. There’s a drastic tonal shift roughly 2/3 into the movie and narrative choices that defy the rules of the world entirely, most notably the ending which left me more frustrated than excited.

The film stars Lupita Nyong'o (The Jungle Book, Black Panther) and Winston Duke (Black Panther) in leading roles as the parents, alongside Shahadi Wright Joseph (The Lion King 2019), and Evan Alex, all of which are fantastic, particularly Nyong’o and Duke. Watching the pair play two drastically different roles was fascinating, particularly Nyong’os doppelganger Red, who acts as the leader of the group. Overall, I still found the movie to be entertaining and would recommend watching it. I like Peele’s style of film making and anticipate a bright future for the writer/director.

Marvel Studio’s Captain Marvel

Originally I planned to review Captain Marvel as I do with all Marvel films, but I’ve been struggling to compile my thoughts without a second viewing and there are too many films out this month for me to see this again so soon. First and foremost, I liked Captain Marvel a lot. It’s an MCU film and that guarantees a certain level of quality; it’s fun, action-packed, great characters, and helps build the larger universe, where we’ll see a payoff in Avengers: Endgame releasing later this month.

Captain Marvel is a prequel film that tells the origin story of the titular character Carol Danvers played by Brie Larson (Room, Kong: Skull Island). The story follows a war between two alien races known as the Kree (previously seen in Guardians of the Galaxy) and the villainous shape-shifting Skrulls, which makes its way to Earth where Carol meets a much younger Nick Fury (Samual L. Jackson), Agent Coulson (Clark Gregg), and her old friend Maria from the Air Force. The film also stars Jude Law as Carol’s Kree mentor Yon-Rogg, Ben Mendelsohn as Talos the leader of the Skrull army, and Lee Pace and Djimon Hounson reprising their Guardian’s roles as Ronan the Accuser and Korath respectively.

I’ve always been excited about Brie Larson playing Captain Marvel, but the initial trailers made her come off as a little bland and out of place. That is certainly not the case in the film. Brie Larson is fantastic as Captain Marvel and her chemistry with Samuel L. Jackson is a lot of fun to watch. It’s refreshing to see this badass female heroine and not have the focus of her story be nothing more than a love story. She’s doesn’t have a love interest at all and her relationships with the rest of the cast range from mentorship, to friend, partners, and family. Carol Danvers is trying to figure out who she is and what her purpose in the world is, nothing more. As far as origin stories go, there’s nothing done here that’s overtly original, and it feels very much like a mixture between Phase One and Phase Three MCU.

Overall, Captain Marvel is a great watch that sits somewhere in the middle of the MCU for me. It’s not one of the best, but it’s also not one of the worst. I think the cast is fantastic, she’s a great role model for young girls to look up to, especially those that like comics and superheroes, and I’m really excited to see the future of Carol Danvers now that the origin story is out of the way.

Modern Warfare Remastered

I stopped playing Call of Duty years ago at this point; I’m just not interested in playing same games year on year, especially a series that becomes increasingly more anti-consumer. But I have a strong fondness and nostalgia for the older games including the Modern Warfare trilogy and my all-time favourite, Black Ops (a game I desperately want to see given the Remastered treatment). I was really excited when MWR was first announced but I never picked it up due to a large backlog, and Activision’s steep prices like reselling the DLC on a Remastered product at a higher cost than the original…

In March, MWR was released for free on PlayStation Plus and was the first game I downloaded when I picked up a PS4 again after a couple of months without one. And after two weeks I’ve already gotten the Platinum trophy! I had a blast going back to Modern Warfare for the first time in years. I don’t think the campaign is as incredible as our memories make it out to be, but it has some fantastic moments like the mission All Ghillied Up, and characters such as Price that are later fleshed out. You can see how Modern Warfare laid the groundwork for everything we know now, and the Remastered version makes the game look and sounds fantastic. Gameplay feels a little dated, particularly the geometry as you’ll find yourself getting literally caught on door frames, but it never ruined my experience.

Modern Warfare was always known for its Multiplayer and that’s something I plan to keep coming back to for the foreseeable future. Multiplayer is a mixture between new school and old school gameplay; it’s still very chaotic, but far simpler than more recent titles. Something as simple as having set kill streaks makes me more focussed on the objective than my streak which is refreshing. Personally, I really like the addition of new weapons and maps as well. And while the loot box system is a lot friendlier than Black Ops 4, loot is my only real problem with MWR. There are too many items for too many weapons and it takes too long to earn anything meaningful without spending money. As a new player, it’s overwhelming and distracting. Whatever happened to trying to get headshots to unlock the Fall camo in MW2?

Apex: Legends Impressions

Titanfall 2 was one of my favourite games of 2016 and easily one of the most underrated games to release that year. So when I heard Respawn Entertainment was releasing a free Battle Royale set in the Titanfall universe, I knew I had to try it out. After playing for a few hours the other night and securing my first win after three games, I’ve already bought the Battle Pass.

Apex: Legends is a squad-based Battle Royale with each game featuring 20 squads of 3 fighting it out for victory. Players can choose from 9 Legend characters to play as (with more coming each season) each with their own unique play styles and abilities, think Fortnite meets Overwatch, which helps distinguish Apex from the other BR games out there. Apex looks, sounds, and plays like a Titanfall game only there’s no Titans or wall running so the overall pace is slower. And the arsenal is taken directly from Titanfall 2 so anyone familiar with those games will feel at home pretty quickly. 

Respawn Entertainment is a developer I like and want to see succeed because they make high-quality games that are fun to play. I also really like the Battle Pass system in Apex because it rewards hardcore players. If you reach Tier 100 and unlock all the rewards, you’ve also unlocked enough Apex coins to buy next Battle Pass without paying anything extra. I’m more than happy to buy the Battle Pass to support a great game that was free, and if that gets me all of the future content because I love the game and play it a lot, fantastic.

Looking for more from me? Follow me on Twitter to keep up to date with my latest posts, video game related nonsense, or if you just want to say hey!

summary: Unpopular Opinion?
title: Unpopular Opinion?
body:
Maria Rambeau x Captain Marvel (Carol Danvers)

I’d love a lesbian relationship (or really any kind of main character that is apart of the LGBTG+ community) but as much as I really wanted to feel it I did not get those vibes from these two.

And I’ve been thinking long and hard since I saw it, maybe my mind will change when I watch a few more times or as the story goes on. The only thing I do kind of feel is that maybe at some point that they might have done something romantically/sexually and it just didn’t work and they were mature enough to move past it and still be each other’s greatest support. But that’s about it (I feel) that could’ve happened or will, there just doesn’t seem to be that kind of chemistry between them.



Edit: IN THE MOVIE. I don’t feel chemistry between the two characters in the movie, to me they just don’t feel romantic. 


That’s basically what I was trying to say, takes me a while to get wording right.
